'''HMS ''Levant''''' was a 28-gun [[Coventry class frigate|''Coventry''-class]] [[sixth-rate]] [[Sailing frigate|frigate]] of the [[Royal Navy]], which saw active service in both the [[Seven Years' War]] and the [[American Revolutionary War]]. [[Ceremonial ship launching|Launched]] in 1758 during a period of war with France, ''Levant'' was assigned to the Royal Navy's [[Jamaica Station (Royal Navy)|Jamaica station]] and proved her worth in defeating nine French vessels during her first three years at sea. She was also part of the fleet for the [[British expedition against Martinique]] in 1762 but played no role in the landings or subsequent defeat of French forces at [[Fort Royal]].
She was [[ship decommissioning|decommissioned]] following Britain's declaration of peace with France in 1763, but returned to active service during the American Revolutionary War. For this conflict she was assigned to the Mediterranean as part of a small British squadron based at [[Gibraltar]]. Over the next three years she captured or sank a total of fourteen enemy craft including an 18-gun American [[privateer]]. In 1779 she brought home news of an impending Spanish assault on Gibraltar, ahead of Spain's declaration of war on Great Britain. The ageing frigate was again decommissioned later that year and her crew discharged to other vessels. She was [[Ship breaking|broken up]] at [[Deptford Dockyard]] in 1780, having secured a total of 24 victories over 21 years at sea.
== Construction == ''Levant'' was an oak-built 28-gun sixth-rate, one of 18 vessels forming part of the ''Coventry''-class of frigates. As with others in her class she was loosely modelled on the design and dimensions of {{HMS|Tartar|1756|6}}, launched in 1756 and responsible for capturing five French privateers in her first twelve months at sea.<ref name=Winfield227>Winfield 2007, p. 227</ref> [[Admiralty]] contracts for ''Levant''{{'}}s construction were issued on 20 May 1757 to a commercial [[shipwright]], [[Henry Adams (shipbuilder)|Henry Adams]] of [[Buckler's Hard]]. The contracts stipulated that work should be completed within ten months, for a vessel measuring approximately 586 [[Builder's Old Measurement|tons burthen]] at a fee of £9.5s a ton. The [[keel]] was laid down in June 1757 but work proceeded slowly and the vessel was not ready for launch until July 1758. In final construction her hull was also larger than contracted, at 595<small>{{fraction|34|94}}</small> tons.<ref name=Winfield229>Winfield 2007, pp. 229–230</ref>
Operating independently of the Royal Dockyards, Adams made several changes to the ''Tartar'' design. In ''Levant'' the ship's wheel was moved from behind the [[mizzen mast]] to before it, and the [[tiller]] shifted from the quarterdeck to an internal location in the hold.<ref name=Gardiner76>Gardiner 1992, p. 76</ref> The [[hawsehole]]s were shifted from the lower to the upper deck to allow additional storage space inside the hull.<ref>Gardiner 1992, p.18</ref> Finally, in recognition of the vessels' likely role in chasing small enemy craft, the leading pair of gunports were moved from the sides of the vessel to the bow to form a battery of [[chase gun]]s.<ref name=Gardiner76/>
As built, ''Levant'' was {{convert|118|ft|5|in|m|1|abbr=on}} long with a {{convert|97|ft|4|in|m|1|abbr=on}} keel, a [[Beam (nautical)|beam]] of {{convert|33|ft|11|in|m|abbr=on}}, and a [[Hold (ship)|hold]] depth of {{convert|10|ft|6|in|m|1|abbr=on}}.<ref name=Winfield229/> Her armament comprised 24 [[Naval long gun|nine-pounder cannons]] located along her gun deck, supported by four three-pounder cannons on the [[quarterdeck]] and twelve {{fraction|1|2}}-pounder [[swivel guns]] ranged along her sides. Her complement was 200 officers and [[Naval rating|ratings]].<ref name=Winfield227/>
==Seven Years' War== [[File:Guadeloupe Banat 1.1.png|thumb|left|Guadeloupe, where ''Levant'' was stationed in 1759.]]
===1758–1760=== ''Levant'' was launched on 6 July 1758 and sailed to [[Portsmouth Dockyard]] for fitout and to take on armament and crew. She was formally commissioned in October under the command of Captain William Tucker, entering Royal Navy service during the early stages of the Seven Years' War against France and Spain. There were delays in mustering sufficient crew, and the frigate was not finally ready to put to sea until June 1759. On 14 June Captain Tucker received orders to take position off [[Guadaloupe]] and the [[Leeward Islands]],<ref name=Winfield229/> there to join a squadron commanded by Commodore John Moore.<ref name=Moore>{{cite news|title =London | work =The Caledonian Mercury | page =1 | publisher =Walter Ruddiman, John Richardson and Company|location=Edinburgh | date =19 July 1760| url =http://www.britishnewspaperarchive.co.uk/viewer/bl/0000045/17600719/003/0001|via=[[British Newspaper Archive]]|subscription=yes | accessdate =20 July 2016 }}</ref> ''Levant'' set sail for this assignment on 23 July.<ref name=Winfield229/><ref>{{cite news|title =London | work =The Newcastle Courant | page =1 | publisher =John White|location=Newcastle, United Kingdom | date =23 June 1759| url =http://www.britishnewspaperarchive.co.uk/viewer/bl/0000085/17590623/002/0001|via=[[British Newspaper Archive]]|subscription=yes | accessdate =17 July 2016 }}</ref>
The British squadron of which ''Levant'' was part was tasked with disrupting French trade through the Caribbean, and with hunting privateers. However the frigate saw little action in her first six months in the region; French trade had virtually ceased since the outbreak of war with Britain, while a smallpox outbreak killed many of ''Levant''{{'}}s crew. It was not until early 1760 when ''Levant'' encountered her first opponent, a 14-gun French privateer which was swiftly defeated and sunk with the loss of 120 of her crew.<ref name=Manchester/> Thereafter combat was more frequent. Two small privateers were captured in early 1760 - the 8-gun ''Poissan Volante'' and the 12-gun ''St Pierre'' - and these vessels and their crews delivered into British custody on the Leeward Islands.<ref name=Moore/> In June ''Pickering'', a British merchantman previously captured by the French, was retaken and sailed to Antigua as ''Levant''{{'}}s prize.<ref name=Pickering>{{cite news|title =London| work =The Caledonian Mercury | page =2 | publisher =Walter Ruddiman, John Richardson and Company|location=Edinburgh | date =6 September 1760| url =http://www.britishnewspaperarchive.co.uk/viewer/bl/0000045/17600906/004/0002|via=[[British Newspaper Archive]]|subscription=yes | accessdate =22 July 2016 }}</ref> A further victory followed on 29 June with the capture of French privateer ''Le Scipio'',<ref name=Winfield229/><ref>{{cite news|title =Admiralty Office, February 28| work =The Derby Mercury | page =3 | publisher =S. Drewry|location=Derby, United Kingdom | date =27 February 1761| url =http://www.britishnewspaperarchive.co.uk/viewer/bl/0000189/17610227/012/0003|via=[[British Newspaper Archive]]|subscription=yes | accessdate =22 July 2016 }}</ref> after which ''Levant'' was put into harbour in Antigua for resupply. One contemporary source at this time records her as carrying only 20 of her 28 guns.<ref>{{cite news|title =Extract of a Letter from St John's in Antigua, to a Merchant in Cork, July 23, 1760| work =The Derby Mercury | page =1 | publisher =S. Drewry|location=Derby, United Kingdom | date =17 October 1760| url =http://www.britishnewspaperarchive.co.uk/viewer/bl/0000189/17601017/014/0003|via=[[British Newspaper Archive]]|subscription=yes | accessdate =22 July 2016 }}</ref> She returned to sea before the end of the year, capturing the privateer ''L'Union'' on 18 December.<ref name=Winfield229/>
===1761–62=== {{Quote box|bgcolor=#E0E6F8| |title = |quote = "The Clerk of our Ship is dead, and several others of the Ship's Company; many people die daily of the Small Pox, which distemper is all over the island of Antigua ...
[The French] dependence is on their privateers; the seas swarm with them." |source = — Extract of a letter from a crew member of ''Levant'', describing conditions aboard in 1759–60.<ref name=Manchester>{{cite news|title =Extract of a Letter from on board the Levant Man of War, at Antigua, dated March 20| work =The Manchester Mercury | page =1 | publisher =Joseph Harrop|location=Manchester, United Kingdom | date =6 May 1760| url =http://www.britishnewspaperarchive.co.uk/viewer/bl/0000239/17600506/002/0001|via=[[British Newspaper Archive]]|subscription=yes | accessdate =19 July 2016 }}</ref> |align = right | width = 25% }} British military successes in European waters in 1760 offered freedom for the Navy to support offensive operations in the Caribbean in the following year. In January General Jeffrey Amherst set sail from North America to the Caribbean with 2,000 men and four ships of the line, for a planned invasion of [[Dominica|French Dominica]].<ref>Robson 2016, p. 173</ref> ''Levant'' saw little action in advance of Amherst's arrival and captured only one vessel, the privateer ''La Catherine'', on 15 February.<ref>{{cite news|title =Extract of a Letter from St Christopher's| work =The Caledonian Mercury | page =2 | publisher =Walter Ruddiman, John Richardson & Company|location=Edinburgh | date =27 April 1761| url =http://www.britishnewspaperarchive.co.uk/viewer/bl/0000045/17610427/007/0002|via=[[British Newspaper Archive]]|subscription=yes | accessdate =19 July 2016 }}</ref> Amherst arrived in Antigua shortly after this capture; Captain Tucker was then deputised to carry the general aboard ''Levant'' for a visit to the various Leeward Island settlements while the invasion force assembled at Guadeloupe.<ref>{{cite news|title =Extract of a Letter from St John's, Antigua, March 11 | work =The Caledonian Mercury | page =2 | publisher =Walter Ruddiman, John Richardson and Company|location=Edinburgh | date =9 May 1761| url =http://www.britishnewspaperarchive.co.uk/viewer/bl/0000045/17610509/008/0002|via=[[British Newspaper Archive]]|subscription=yes | accessdate =22 July 2016 }}</ref> Amherst departed the Leeward Islands in April and ''Levant'' resumed her hunt for privateers, capturing ''La Dulcinée'' on 13 July and ''L'Aventurier'' six days later.<ref name=Winfield229/>
Dominica having fallen to Amherst's forces in June, the British then set their sights on the French stronghold of [[Martinique]]. Britain's [[Secretary of State for the Southern Department]], Sir [[William Pitt, 1st Earl of Chatham|William Pitt]], considered that Martinique's capture would be the decisive battle for control of the Caribbean, and instructed that all available resources be committed to its invasion. An army of 13,000 troops was assembled, supported by a fleet under Admiral [[George Rodney]].<ref>Robson 2016, pp. 174–175</ref> ''Levant'' was added to Rodney's sizeable command in late 1761 and sailed as part of the expedition in January 1762.<ref name=Winfield229/><ref>{{cite news|title =Extract of a Letter from Guadeloupe, December 7| work =The Derby Mercury | page =1 | publisher =S. Drewry|location=Derby, United Kingdom | date =5 February 1762| url =http://www.britishnewspaperarchive.co.uk/viewer/bl/0000189/17620205/015/0002|via=[[British Newspaper Archive]]|subscription=yes | accessdate =23 July 2016 }}</ref> She saw no engagement with enemy vessels during the landings or the assault on Fort Royal between 25 January and 3 February.<ref name=Winfield229/>
''Levant'' then returned to her station off the Leeward Islands, arriving there on 10 February. Ten days later, Tucker received orders from Admiral Rodney transferring ''Levant'' to the command of Captain [[John Laforey]], previously of the [[fifth-rate]] {{HMS|Echo|1758|6}}.<ref name=Winfield229/><ref>Winfield 2007, p.276</ref> Under Laforey's command the vessel made one final capture, seizing the French privateer ''La Fier'' on 13 May.<ref name=Winfield229/><ref>{{cite news|title =Letter from Charlestown, South-Carolina, July '14 | work =The Caledonian Mercury | page =3 | publisher =Walter Ruddiman, John Richardson and Company|location=Edinburgh | date =23 August 1762| url =http://www.britishnewspaperarchive.co.uk/viewer/bl/0000045/17620823/012/0003|via=[[British Newspaper Archive]]|subscription=yes | accessdate =23 July 2016 }}</ref>
[[Treaty of Paris (1763)|Peace with France]] was established in March 1763 and ''Levant'' was declared surplus to the Navy's needs. Captain Laforey departed the vessel and command transferred to a Captain Shouldham for the voyage back to England. ''Levant'' reached [[Portsmouth Dockyard]] in August 1763, where she was decommissioned and most of her crew discharged or reassigned.<ref name=Winfield229/><ref>{{cite news|title =Extract of a Letter from Portsmouth, August 14 | work =The Caledonian Mercury | page =2 | publisher =Walter Ruddiman, John Richardson and Company|location=Edinburgh | date =20 August 1763| url =http://www.britishnewspaperarchive.co.uk/viewer/bl/0000045/17630820/003/0002|via=[[British Newspaper Archive]]|subscription=yes | accessdate =23 July 2016 }}</ref>

Date|| Ship || Nationality|| Type ||Fate |- | March 1760 | Not recorded | French | Privateer, 14 guns | Sunk |- | By April 1760 | ''Poissan Volante'' | French | Privateer, 8 guns | Captured |- | 29 April 1760 | ''Le Saint Pierre'' | French | Privateer, 12 guns | Captured |- | June 1760 | ''Pickering'' | British | Merchant vessel | Recaptured |- | 29 June 1760 | ''Le Scipio'' | French | Privateer, 10 guns | Captured |- | 18 December 1760 | ''L'Union'' | French | Privateer | Captured |- | 15 February 1761 | ''La Catherine'' | French | Privateer, 10 guns | Captured |- | 13 July 1761 | ''La Dulcinée | French | Privateer | Captured |- | 19 July 1761 | ''L'Aventurier'' | French | Privateer | Captured |- | 13 May 1762 | ''Le Fier'' | French | Privateer | Captured |- |}
==Peacetime service == Despite the declaration of peace there were rumours that ''Levant'' would swiftly return to active service.<ref>{{cite news|title =London| work =The Derby Mercury | page =3 | publisher =S. Drewry|location=Derby, United Kingdom | date =19 August 1763| url =http://www.britishnewspaperarchive.co.uk/viewer/bl/0000189/17630819/017/0003|via=[[British Newspaper Archive]]|subscription=yes | accessdate =23 July 2016 }}</ref> However these proved unfounded and she remained tied up at Portsmouth. Her hull and fittings were surveyed in late 1763 to determine maintenance requirements, but no repairs were made.<ref name=Winfield229/> In September 1763 a member of her [[skeleton crew]] was robbed and murdered at [[Liphook]], a village some distance from Portsmouth.<ref>{{cite news|title =Conditions| work =The Derby Mercury | page =2 | publisher =S. Drewry|location=Derby, United Kingdom | date =23 September 1763| url =http://www.britishnewspaperarchive.co.uk/viewer/bl/0000189/17630923/009/0002|via=[[British Newspaper Archive]]|subscription=yes | accessdate =23 July 2016 }}</ref>
''Levant'' returned to Navy service in 1766 under the command of Captain Basil Keith, and was assigned to patrol and convoy duties on the Navy's [[Jamaica Station (Royal Navy)|Jamaica Station]]. In August she was relocated to [[Deptford Dockyard|Deptford]] to take on crew and supplies, setting sail for the Caribbean on 28 November.<ref name=Winfield229/><ref>{{cite news|title =Edinburgh | work =The Caledonian Mercury | page =3 | publisher =Walter Ruddiman, John Richardson and Company|location=Edinburgh | date =1 September 1766| url =http://www.britishnewspaperarchive.co.uk/viewer/bl/0000045/17660901/006/0003|via=[[British Newspaper Archive]]|subscription=yes | accessdate =30 July 2016 }}</ref> She held her Jamaica post for three years, but this extensive service in tropical waters had left her in poor condition. In 1770 she returned to Deptford Dockyard where she was decommissioned and hauled out of the water for rebuilding. The work was granted to shipwright John Dudman and took six months from November 1770 to April 1771. Repair and rebuilding expenses were £5,869 with an additional £3,059 for fitout, amounting to considerably more than the vessel's original construction cost of £5,423.<ref name=Winfield229/>
The rebuilt frigate was recommissioned in August 1771 under Captain Samuel Thompson. After four months in home waters she was assigned to the Navy's Mediterranean squadron and took up position off Gibraltar in January 1772. ''Levant'' remained at this station for three years, her uneventful service broken only by a 1773 transfer of command from Captain Thompson to Captain [[George Murray (Royal Navy officer, born 1741)|George Murray]], the son of former [[Jacobitism|Jacobite]] commander [[Lord George Murray (general)|Lord Murray]].<ref name=Winfield229/>
==American Revolutionary War==
===1775–1777=== {{Quote box|bgcolor=#E0E6F8| |title = |quote = "''Levant'' ordered her to strike; the Captain of the Privateer said she would not, upon which he was told by the ''Levant''{{'}}s people that they would in a few minutes sink her ... the Privateer immediately struck without firing a gun." |source = — A contemporaneous account of the capture of the 14-gun American privateer ''General Montgomery'', March 1777.<ref name=Montgomery>{{cite news|title =London, Saturday April 12| work =The Derby Mercury | page =2 | publisher =John Drewry|location=Derby, United Kingdom | date =11 April 1777| url =http://www.britishnewspaperarchive.co.uk/viewer/bl/0000189/17770411/009/0002|via=[[British Newspaper Archive]]|subscription=yes | accessdate =31 July 2016 }}</ref> |align = right | width = 25% }} ''Levant'' was returned to Portsmouth in early 1775 but put to sea again at the outbreak of the American Revolutionary War.<ref name=Winfield229/> Captain Murray's orders were to join a Mediterranean squadron under the overall command of Captain [[Robert Mann (Royal Navy officer)|Robert Mann]], there to intercept and capture American merchant shipping. While at sea Murray also took the opportunity to train his crew in seamanship and battle techniques, in preparation for future enemy engagement.<ref name=UMich>{{cite web| title =Finding aid for HMS Levant and HMS Arethusa Log Book, 1775–1777 | publisher =William L. Clements Library, University of Michigan | year =2015 | url =http://quod.lib.umich.edu/c/clementsmss/umich-wcl-M-5030.11lev?view=text | accessdate =31 July 2016 }}</ref> In March 1776 she anchored in the Bay of Algiers where the [[Dey of Algiers|Dey]] received her warmly and provided the crew with supplies including bread, vegetables, and three live sheep.<ref name=UMich/>
Mediterranean trade was busy, and ''Levant'' took part in the halting and examination of vessels of various nationalities, including Dutch, Genoese, Spanish, and the British Caribbean.<ref name=UMich/> Neutral shipping was permitted to continue on its way. However ''Levant'' detained a South Carolina merchantman named ''Dolphin'' in October 1776 on suspicion of being a supply vessel for the rebels, and sent her into Gibraltar along with her cargo of rice.<ref>Clark (ed.) et. al 2012, p. 939</ref> In November 1776 ''Levant'' secured a substantial prize with the capture of another South Carolina vessel, ''Argo'',<ref>{{cite news|title=Admiralty-Office|work=Saunders's News Letter|page=1|url=http://www.britishnewspaperarchive.co.uk/viewer/bl/0001057/17761220/002/0001|date=20 December 1776|publisher=J. Poris|accessdate =31 July 2016|via=[[British Newspaper Archive]]|subscription=yes}}</ref> carrying rice and indigo worth £37,200, or £4.5 million in 2015 terms.<ref>{{cite news|title =Admiralty-Office, December 13|work =The Hampshire Chronicle | page =3 | publisher =J. Linden and J. Hodson|location=Southampton | date =16 December 1776| url =http://www.britishnewspaperarchive.co.uk/viewer/bl/0000230/17761216/003/0003|via=[[British Newspaper Archive]]|subscription=yes | accessdate =31 July 2016 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web| title =Purchasing Power of British Pounds from 1264 to Present| publisher =Measuring Worth | date =2016 | url =https://www.measuringworth.com/ukcompare/result.php?year_source=1776&amount=37200&year_result=2015| accessdate =31 July 2016 }}</ref> ''Argo'' was to have exchanged her cargo in Bordeaux for clothing and medicine to supply the American rebellion.<ref>{{cite news|title =Extract of a Letter from a merchant at Lisbon, to his Brother in Birmingham, dated December 1, 1776| work =The Derby Mercury | page =4 | publisher =John Drewry|location=Derby, United Kingdom | date =13 December 1776| url =http://www.britishnewspaperarchive.co.uk/viewer/bl/0000189/17761213/018/0004|via=[[British Newspaper Archive]]|subscription=yes | accessdate =31 July 2016 }}</ref>
Further success followed in early 1777 with the capture of the 18-gun American privateer ''General Montgomery''.<ref name=Winfield229/> News had reached England that this vessel was off the island of [[Madeira]] in March, having sailed from Philadelphia in February with a crew of 100 men. ''Levant'' was sent in pursuit, with her crew sighting the ''General Montgomery'' at midday on 8 March. Captain Murray ordered ''Levant'' to fly [[false colours]], hoisting a Dutch flag to avoid alerting the privateer's crew.<ref name=Montgomery/> ''General Montgomery'' had also disguised herself by flying a British flag. For several hours the Americans allowed ''Levant'' to draw near, but turned to flee when Murray fired a warning shot. A seven-hour chase ensued, extending into the night with the two ships within musket shot but unable to bring their broadside cannons to bear. At around 1:00{{nbsp}}am the wind strengthened and ''Levant'' was able to overhaul her prey, forcing the out-gunned Americans to surrender. Nine of ''General Montgomery''{{'}}s crew enlisted aboard ''Levant'', with the remainder being conveyed to Portsmouth where they remained imprisoned in poor conditions until the end of the war.<ref>Captain George Murray RN to Captain William Hay, HMS ''Alarm'', 14 March 1777. Cited in Clark (ed.) et. al. volume 8, 1980, pp. 676–677</ref><ref>Clark (ed.) et. al. volume 11, 2005, pp. 888–892</ref>
===1778–1780=== [[File:USS Revenge (1777).jpg|thumb|left|The American privateer ''USS Revenge''. In 1778 she narrowly escaped from ''Levant'' and found safe harbour in Cadiz.]] ''Levant'' continued her Mediterranean patrols in 1778 and was rewarded on 24 March with the recapture of a British merchantman which had been bound for Newfoundland when seized by an American privateer off Gibraltar.<ref name=Ipswich>{{cite news|title =Extract of a letter from Gibraltar, March 27| work =The Ipswich Journal | page =2 | publisher =J. Shave, E. Craighton and S. Jackson|location=Ipswich, United Kingdom | date =2 May 1778| url =http://www.britishnewspaperarchive.co.uk/viewer/bl/0000071/17780502/009/0002|via=[[British Newspaper Archive]]|subscription=yes | accessdate =1 August 2016 }}</ref> On the same day as this capture, ''Levant'' fell into company with the 28-gun frigate {{HMS|Enterprise|1774|6}}. Her captain, Sir Thomas Rich, advised that he was pursuing the [[USS Revenge (1777)|USS ''Revenge'']], a 22-gun American privateer with three captured merchant ships in tow. On 21 March the privateer had surprised and destroyed ''Enterprise''{{'}}s [[tender (boat)|tender]] before escaping into the night. Rich had given chase for the next three days; Murray now added ''Levant'' to the hunt and the two British frigates set courses to [[windward and leeward]] of the Americans' likely path. Both sailed through the night without sighting their prey. In the morning of 25 March they encountered one of ''Revenge''{{'}}s prizes - the 16-gun British merchantman ''Hope'' - which promptly surrendered and was returned to Gibraltar.<ref name=Ipswich/> ''Revenge'' herself eluded capture and was later reported as having escaped to the neutral Spanish port of Cadiz.<ref>Clark (ed.) et. al. volume 12, p. 525</ref>
France entered the War against Britain after signing a formal [[Treaty of Alliance (1778)|Treaty]] with the United States in March 1778. There was a subsequent reorganization of Royal Navy forces in the Mediterranean, with ''Levant'' joining a squadron of four other vessels based in Gibraltar and under the overall direction of Admiral Robert Duff. Of this squadron, ''Levant'' was the second largest, behind only Duff's 60-gun flagship {{HMS|Panther|1758|6}}.<ref>{{cite news|title =The Following is a Correct List of the Marine Forces of Great Britain with their present Stations| work =The Hampshire Chronicle | page =4 | publisher =J. Wilkes|location=Winchester | date =14 September 1778| url =http://www.britishnewspaperarchive.co.uk/viewer/bl/0000230/17780914/008/0004|via=[[British Newspaper Archive]]|subscription=yes | accessdate =4 August 2016 }}</ref> In July ''Levant'' encountered and captured ''Robert'', an American merchant vessel that had been bound for Boston with a cargo of salt.<ref>{{cite news|title =Dublin| work =Hibernian Journal: Or, Chronicle of Liberty | page =3 | publisher =T. M'Donnell|location=Dublin | date =27 July 1778| url =http://www.britishnewspaperarchive.co.uk/viewer/bl/0000817/17780727/009/0003|via=[[British Newspaper Archive]]|subscription=yes | accessdate =4 August 2016 }}</ref> In August she took her first French prize of the War - a merchantman with a cargo of tobacco - and recaptured the British schooner ''Lively'', which had previously been seized by an American privateer off Scotland's [[Outer Hebrides|Western Islands]].<ref>{{cite news|title =Extract of a letter from Gibraltar, August 19 | work =The Caledonian Mercury | page =3 | publisher =John Robertson|location=Edinburgh | date =28 September 1778| url =http://www.britishnewspaperarchive.co.uk/viewer/bl/0000045/17780928/010/0003|via=[[British Newspaper Archive]]|subscription=yes | accessdate =20 July 2016 }}</ref> Two more French prizes followed; ''Victorieux'' seized ''en route'' to Marseilles, and ''Duchess of Grumont'', which surrendered off Toulon. ''Levant'' sent both captured vessels in to Gibraltar with their cargoes.<ref>{{cite news|title=Dublin|work=Saunders's News Letter|page=2|url=http://www.britishnewspaperarchive.co.uk/viewer/bl/0001057/17781001/009/0002|date=1 October 1778|publisher=J. Poris|accessdate =4 August 2016|via=[[British Newspaper Archive]]|subscription=yes}}</ref>
These ongoing victories belied the changing conditions applicable to ''Levant''{{'}}s hunt for enemy vessels off Gibraltar. American vessels had become scarce, especially since Spain had closed her ports to them in the winter of 1777 in retaliation for privateer attacks on Spanish ships.<ref>Clark (ed.) et. al volume 11, p. 860</ref> French trading vessels remained at sea but were occasionally accompanied by naval escorts large enough to prevent their capture by Gibraltar's small Royal Navy squadron.<ref name=Harrop>{{cite news|title =Extract of a Letter from Gibraltar, January 31| work =The Manchester Mercury | page =1 | publisher =Joseph Harrop|location=Manchester, United Kingdom | date =16 March 1779| url =http://www.britishnewspaperarchive.co.uk/viewer/bl/0000239/17790316/001/0001|via=[[British Newspaper Archive]]|subscription=yes | accessdate =6 August 2016 }}</ref> ''Levant'' was [[careening|careened]] on a beach at Gibraltar over Christmas 1778 and then returned to sea, but her next capture was not until 1 April 1779 when, in company with Captain Rich's ''Enterprise'', she seized a French ship carrying wine and [[brandy]] from Marseilles.<ref name=Harrop/><ref>{{cite news|title =Ships taken from the French and Americans| work =The Leeds Intelligencer | page =3 | publisher =Griffith Wright and Son|location=Leeds, United Kingdom | date =11 May 1779| url =http://www.britishnewspaperarchive.co.uk/viewer/bl/0000236/17790511/006/0003|via=[[British Newspaper Archive]]|subscription=yes | accessdate =6 August 2016 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Foreign Intelligence|work=Saunders's News Letter|page=1|url=http://www.britishnewspaperarchive.co.uk/viewer/bl/0001057/17790526/001/0001|date=26 May 1779|publisher=J. Poris|accessdate =6 August 2016|via=[[British Newspaper Archive]]|subscription=yes}}</ref>
That same month Spain signed the [[Treaty of Aranjuez (1779)|Treaty of Aranjuez]] with France, setting terms for a military alliance against Britain. Despite the Treaty, Spain delayed the issue of a formal declaration of war.<ref name=Dull>Dull 2009, pp. 102–103</ref> In the interim ''Levant'' engaged and defeated a Spanish privateer whose crew ''Levant'' caught in the act of boarding a British merchant ship. A brief exchange of cannon fire holed the Spanish vessel below the waterline, sinking her; ''Levant'' rescued the majority of her crew and transported them to prison in Gibraltar.<ref>{{cite news|title=London, June 18|work=Saunders's News Letter|page=1|url=http://www.britishnewspaperarchive.co.uk/viewer/bl/0001057/17790624/001/0001|date=24 June 1779|publisher=J. Poris|accessdate =6 August 2016|via=[[British Newspaper Archive]]|subscription=yes}}</ref>
Captain Murray then took ''Levant'' on a cruise to hunt for French or American vessels off Cadiz. While pursuing this task in late June 1779 he ran across the Spanish battle fleet, comprising 32 [[ship of the line|ships of the line]] and two frigates, heading south towards an unknown destination.<ref>{{cite news|title=Sunday's Post|work=The Ipswich Journal|page=1|url=http://www.britishnewspaperarchive.co.uk/viewer/bl/0000071/17790731/001/0001|date=31 July 1779|publisher=J. Shave and S. Jackson|accessdate =13 August 2016|via=[[British Newspaper Archive]]|subscription=yes}}</ref> Spain was still nominally a neutral power and after a brief exchange of pleasantries the Spanish fleet left ''Levant'' unmolested and continued on its way. Murray immediately set sail for England to report that the Spanish were at sea, pausing off [[Land's End]] on 17 July to capture the French privateer ''La Revanche''.<ref>{{cite news|title =Home News|work =The Hampshire Chronicle | page =3 | publisher =J. Linden and J. Hodson|location=Southampton, United Kingdom | date =2 August 1779| url =http://www.britishnewspaperarchive.co.uk/viewer/bl/0000230/17790802/004/0003|via=[[British Newspaper Archive]]|subscription=yes | accessdate =13 August 2016 }}</ref> ''Levant'' finally reached Portsmouth in late July but by this time Murray's news of the Spanish fleet was out of date; Spain had already declared war on Britain and her fleet had reached Gibraltar to commence an [[Great Siege of Gibraltar|extended siege]].<ref name=Dull/><ref>{{cite news|title=London, July 24|work=Saunders's News Letter|page=1|url=http://www.britishnewspaperarchive.co.uk/viewer/bl/0001057/17790730/002/0001|date=30 July 1779|publisher=J. Poris|accessdate =13 August 2016|via=[[British Newspaper Archive]]|subscription=yes}}</ref>

==Final voyages== {{Quote box|bgcolor=#E0E6F8| |title = |quote ="[t]he ''Levant'' was, after the commencement of the American war, extremely successful, having captured so considerable a number of prizes that few vessels, perhaps, have ever quitted a station with more éclat respecting herself, and more regret from the officers and other persons concerned, who derived advantage from her good fortune and the activity of her people" |source = — First Lieutenant Erasmus Gower, reflecting on ''Levant''{{'}}s role in the American Revolutionary War.<ref name=UMich/> |align = right | width = 25% }} Murray was ordered to take ''Levant'' back to sea immediately, departing Portsmouth on 27 July as escort to a convoy of merchant vessels bound for the Yorkshire port of [[Kingston upon Hull]].<ref>{{cite news|title=London, July 30|work=Saunders's News Letter|page=1|url=http://www.britishnewspaperarchive.co.uk/viewer/BL/0001057/17790805/003/0001?browse=true|date=5 August 1779|publisher=J. Poris|accessdate =13 August 2016|via=[[British Newspaper Archive]]|subscription=yes}}</ref> The ageing frigate then briefly joined a small Navy squadron on patrol off [[Brighton]] before setting sail for the Spanish coast.<ref>{{cite news|title=London, August 27|work=Saunders's News Letter|page=1|url=http://www.britishnewspaperarchive.co.uk/viewer/bl/0001057/17790902/003/0001|date=2 September 1779|publisher=J. Poris|accessdate =13 August 2016|via=[[British Newspaper Archive]]|subscription=yes}}</ref><ref name=Oct26>{{cite news|title=London, October 21|work=Cumberland Pacquet, and Ware's Whitehaven Advertiser |page=2|url=http://www.britishnewspaperarchive.co.uk/viewer/bl/0000950/17791026/012/0002|date=26 October 1779|publisher=John Ware & Son|accessdate =13 August 2016|via=[[British Newspaper Archive]]|subscription=yes}}</ref> She was off Cadiz in October 1779 when she won her final victory of the war, capturing the 20-gun Spanish privateer ''Velenza de Alcantara'' along with 200 of her crew.<ref name=Oct26/>
By month's end ''Levant'' was back in Portsmouth, where she was decommissioned and her crew discharged to other vessels.<ref name=Winfield229/> She had been at sea for 21 years, outlasting all but four of her sister ships in the ''Coventry'' class.<ref>Winfield 2007, pp. 227–232</ref> Her erstwhile captain, George Murray, was assigned to the newly built {{HMS|Cleopatra|1779|6}}; after extended further service he was promoted to admiral in 1794 and died in 1796.<ref>[http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/40510?docPos=3 George Murray at Oxford Dictionary of National Biography]</ref>
Despite ''Levant''{{'}}s age there was some consideration to restoring her to active service, and as late as 1 August 1780 she was listed as "repairing and will soon be fit for sea."<ref>{{cite news|title=A Complete List of the Navy of Great Britain, with the names of the Captains of each ship, the Fleets on the different stations, and the Ships fitting out, in ordinary and building|work=The Scots Magazine|page=4|url=http://www.britishnewspaperarchive.co.uk/viewer/bl/0000545/17800801/004/0004|date=1 August 1780|accessdate =14 August 2016|via=[[British Newspaper Archive]]|subscription=yes}}</ref> However, in practice no repairs were made, and on 16 August the Admiralty issued orders that she be sailed to [[Deptford Dockyard]] to be broken up. This was enacted, and ''Levant'' was broken up at Deptford by 27 September 1780.<ref name=Winfield229/> Her passing was mourned by her former crew, with their sentiments recorded by First Lieutenant Erasmus Gower in 1800, "having captured so considerable a number of prizes ... few vessels, perhaps, have ever quitted a station with more éclat respecting herself, and more regret from the officers and other persons concerned."<ref name=UMich/>
